{{Infobox University |name = Delaware State University |image_name = Delaware State University seal.jpg |image_size = 210px |caption = |latin_name = |motto = ''"Making our mark on the world"'' and ''"Go forth and serve"'' |mottoeng = |established = May 15, 1891 |closed = |type = [[Public university|Public]], [[land-grant university|Land Grant]], [[HBCU]] |affiliation = |endowment = [[United States dollar|US$]]20.8 million{{cite web|url=http://www.petersons.com/ugchannel/code/InstVC.asp?inunid=6059&sponsor=1 |title=Delaware State University in Dover, Delaware |publisher=Petersons.com |accessdate=2011-09-19}} |officer_in_charge = |chairman = |chancellor = |president = Dr. Harry Lee Williams |vice-president = |superintendent = |provost = |vice_chancellor = |rector = |principal = |dean = |director = |head_label = |head = |faculty = 436 |staff = |students = 4,179{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/dsu-breaks-its-enrollment-record-2nd-consecutive-year|title=DSU Breaks its Enrollment Record for the 2nd Consecutive Year|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2011}} |undergrad = 3,745 |postgrad = 333 |doctoral = 101 |other = |city = [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]] |state = [[Delaware]] |province = |country = [[United States|USA]] |coor = |campus = [[Suburb]]an |former_names = -State College for Colored Students (foundingâ1947)
-Delaware State College (1947-1993) |free_label = |free = |sports = |colors = [[Cerise (color)|Cherry red]] {{color box|#ff0000}} and [[Columbia blue]] {{color box|#0097d8}} |nickname = [[Hornet]] |mascot = |athletics = [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] |affiliations = [[Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference]] |website = {{URL|http://www.desu.edu}} |logo = [[File:DelawareStU.png|320px]] }} '''Delaware State University''' (also referred to as '''DSU''', '''DESU''', or '''Del State'''), is an [[United States|American]] [[Historically black colleges and universities|historically black]], [[public university]] located in [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]], [[Delaware]], and there are two [[satellite campus]]es located in [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]], Delaware, and [[Georgetown, Delaware|Georgetown]], Delaware. With approximately 4,200 students, it is the second-largest university in the state (behind the [[University of Delaware]]) and encompasses six colleges and a diverse population of [[undergraduate]] and [[postgraduate education|advanced-degree]] students. ==History== The '''State College for Colored Students''' was established on May 15, 1891, by the [[Delaware General Assembly]]. It first awarded degrees in 1898. In 1944, the [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools|Middle States Commission on Higher Education]] awarded the college provisional [[accreditation]]. Three years later, the institution became '''Delaware State College''' by legislative action. Although its accreditation was revoked in 1949, it was regained in 1957. On July 1, 1993, the institution changed its name yet again, this time to '''Delaware State University'''.{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/history |title=Delaware State University History |publisher=Delaware State University |accessdate=September 22, 2011}} ===September 21, 2007, campus shootings=== {{main|Delaware State University shooting}} {{Wikinewspar|Two students shot at Delaware State University}} On September 21, 2007, two university students were shot on campus near Memorial Hall around one a.m. Classes were canceled for the day. One student was hospitalized in stable condition, and another student was hospitalized with injuries that were considered serious, according to a news release on the university's web site.{{Dead link|date=November 2009}}{{cite news|author=''[[Associated Press|The Associated Press]]''|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5jAWPn73xdPrG4b9FhHbtCUVgN6Ww|title=2 Students Shot at Delaware State|agency=Associated Press |date=2007-09-21|accessdate=2007-09-21}} The campus was "locked down" with students confined to their dormitories and traffic blocked at the campus gate, through Sunday, September 23. Classes resumed on September 24. On that day, a freshman student was arrested for attempted murder in connection with the incident, and was [[Expulsion (academia)|expelled]] from the university. The episode is significant because it marks the first test of a university's response to a campus shooting following the [[Virginia Tech shootings]] in April 2007. One of the students, a seventeen-year-old freshman, died. ==Campus== The {{convert|400|acre|km2|sing=on}} main campus in [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]], the capital of [[Delaware]], is an approximate two-hour motor drive from [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]]; [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]]; and [[Washington, D.C.]], and three hours from [[New York City]], [[New York]]. There are satellite campuses in [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]] and [[Georgetown, Delaware|Georgetown]]. The main campus in [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]] contains thirty buildings, including: {{multicol}} * Administration Building * [[Alumni Stadium (Delaware State)|Alumni Stadium]] * The Bank of America Building * Delaware Hall * Loockerman Hall {{col-break}} * The Mishoe Science Center * Price Building * Willam C. Jason Library * The Wellness and Recreation Center {{col-end}} There are seven campus residential halls: four for women, and three for men. There are also three apartment-style residence halls for upperclassmen. They include: {{multicol}} * Conwell Hall * [[Harriet Tubman]] Hall * Jenkins Hall * Laws Hall {{col-break}} * [[Medgar Evers]] Hall * University Courtyard Apartments * University Village Complex * Warren-Franklin Hall {{col-end}} Two dining halls serve the more than 1,500 on-campus students. As a part of the [[Internet2]] initiative, the university maintains several research computer laboratories including a high-performance computational cluster in its [[DESAC]] center. Almost every building has a computer lab and each student has a dedicated data port for internet access, their own phone, a campus email address, and cable television access in all residence hall rooms. Most campus buildings also offer wireless connectivity. The university also has two farm properties in the [[Kenton, Delaware|Kenton]] and [[Smyrna, Delaware|Smyrna]] areas, and its Airway Science Program maintains it fleet of planes and base of operation at the Delaware Air Park in [[Cheswold, Delaware|Cheswold]].{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/history|title=History|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}} ==Administration== {| class="infobox" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="2" style="font-size: 90%;" |+ style="font-size: 1.25em;" |'''Presidents''' |- |Wesley P. Webb |1891â1895 |- |William C. Jason |1895â1923 |- |Richard S. Grossley |1923â1942 |- |Howard D. Gregg |1942â1949 |- |Oscard J. Chapman |1950â1951 |- |[[Jerome H. Holland]] |1953â1960 |- |Luna I. Mishoe |1960â1987 |- |William B. DeLauder |1987â2003 |- |Allen L. Sessoms |2003â2008 |- |Harry L. Williams |2010âPresent |} Harry Lee Williams became the 10th president of DSU on Jan. 10, 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/presidential-tenure-highlights|title=The Presidents of Delaware State University and the Highlights of their Tenures|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}} Maurice E. Thomasson served as acting president from 1949 to 1950 and from 1951 to 1953. Claibourne D. Smith served as acting president from September 2008 to November 2009. The business and affairs of the university are governed by the Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees has all the powers accorded it by Title 14, Chapter 65 of the Delaware Code.{{cite web |url=http://delcode.delaware.gov/title14/c065/index.shtml|title=CHAPTER 65. ORGANIZATION, ADMINISTRATION AND FUNCTIONS - Delaware State University|publisher=delcode.delaware.gov - the Online Delaware Code website}} The Board consists of 15 members whose appointment or election is provided for in the Delaware Code, and the [[Governor of Delaware|governor of the state]] and the president of the university, both of whom shall be members of the board, ex officio, with the right to vote.{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/board-trustees|title=Board of Trustees|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}} ==Academics== The university consists of six colleges:[http://www.desu.edu/advancement/pr/press_release.php?article_id=287 Retrieved 2007-09-25.]{{dead link|date=September 2011}} {{multicol}} *College of Mathematics, Natural Sciences and Technology *College of Business *College of Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences {{col-break}} *College of Health and Public Policy *College of Education *College of Agriculture and Related Sciences {{col-end}} The university offers fifty-six undergraduate degrees, twenty-five graduate degrees, and five doctoral degrees ([[interdisciplinary applied mathematics and mathematical physics]], [[applied chemistry]], [[neuroscience]] and [[optics]], and doctorate programs in education).{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/about-dsu|title=About DSU|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}} The university also offers several cooperative and dual degree programs.{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/dtcc-dual-admission-program|title=DTCC Dual Admission Program|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}} Students receive instruction in classes with a 13:1 student-to-faculty ratio. About 83 percent of undergraduates receive scholarships, grants, loans or work-study income.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} It has an Honors Program, an Honors Curriculum, and a [[Minority Access to Research Careers]] (MARC) Honor's Program to increase the number of students in science interested in pursuing biomedical research and obtaining [[doctor of philosophy]] degrees in biology, chemistry, physics, mathematics, computer science, and [[biopsychology]]. In addition to satisfying the requirements for the major or majors and any minor, all undergraduates are required to complete the General Education Program, which includes: seven core courses, twelve foundation courses (across the curriculum), and the Senior Capstone Experience. Accreditations include the [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools|Middle States Commission on Higher Education]] (MSCHE), the [[National League of Nursing Accrediting Commission]] (NLNAC), the [[Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education]] (CCNE), [[Council on Social Work Education]] (CSWE), [[Accreditation Council for Programs in Hospitality Administration]] (ACPHA), the [[National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education]] (NCATE), and [[Commission on Accreditation for Dietetic Education]] (CCDE). The universityâs College of Business is nationally and internationally accredited by the [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] (AACSB).{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/ncate-institution-report-overview|title=NCATE INSTITUTION REPORT OVERVIEW|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}}{{cite web |url=https://www.aacsb.net/eweb/DynamicPage.aspx?Site=AACSB&WebKey=00E50DA9-8BB0-4A32-B7F7-0A92E98DF5C6|title=Schools Accredited in Business|publisher=The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business|year=2011}} ===Unique programs=== DSU's Aviation Program provides students with education and experience in preparation for careers in the [[aviation]] industry. Curricula in the program lead to a [[Bachelor of Science|B.Sc.]] degree with concentrations in Aviation Management or Professional [[Aviator|Pilot]]. Professional Pilot graduates will complete their [[Federal Aviation Administration]] (FAA) requirements for [[Private Pilot]], Instrument, Commercial, Multi-Engine and Certified Flight Instructor ratings while earning their Bachelor's Degree.{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/aviation|title=The Aviation Program|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}} Delaware State operates the only full-service, university-based flight school in the mid-Atlantic area. The Aviation program is approved by the State of Delaware Education Department for Veterans Flight Training.{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/professional-pilot|title=The Professional Pilot Program|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bestaviation.net/school/delaware_state_university/|title=Delaware Flight Schools - Delaware State University |publisher=Best Aviation|year=2011}} ===Research=== The institution has greatly increased its research endeavors over the past several years, as it has developed the research infrastructure needed to attract federal grants for projects in the following DSU Research Centers and in the sciences and mathematics: 1) Applied Mathematics Research Center, numerical analysis of [[partial differential equations]], analytical methods in [[solid mechanics]], [[wavelet]] analysis, [[NURBS]] methods of computer geometric design, [[nonlinear PDE]]s, [[topology]]; 2) The Center for Applied Optics, as well as The Center for Research and Education in Optical Sciences and Applications (CREOSA) (a [[National Science Foundation]]-Center for Research Excellence (NSF-CREST)), [[optical science]] and [[laser physics]] (including [[Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy]]); 3) Center for Applied Optics for Space Science (CAOSS) (a [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] University Research Center (NASA-URC));{{cite web|url=http://www.desu.edu/dsu-receives-5-million-nasa-research-grant |title=DSU Receives $5 million NASA research grant | DSU |publisher=Desu.edu |date=2009-09-30 |accessdate=2011-09-19}} 4) additional physics, including [[mathematical physics]], [[plasma physics]], [[theoretical physics]], [[fluid dynamics]], [[high pressure]] materials, [[semiconductor]] materials and devices, [[geophysics]]; 4) [[Hydrogen storage]] and [[Fuel cell]] Chemistry Center, [[biochemistry]], [[organic chemistry]], [[analytical chemistry]], [[synthetic chemistry]], [[NMR spectroscopy]], [[electrochemistry]], [[phospholipases]]; 5) [[IDeA Networks of Biomedical Research Excellence]] ([[NIH]]-[[INBRE]]), [[cell biology]], [[microbiology]], molecular mechanisms of neuronal function, [[neurobiology]] and behavior, nanobioscience, [[RNA sequencing]]; 6) [[biotechnology]]; 7) Delaware Center for Scientific and Applied Computation, [[computer science]] and [[bioinformatics]], [[data mining]] and [[machine learning]], [[combinatorics]], spatial-temporal [[statistics]], [[artificial neural networks]]); 8) [[neuroscience]]; and 9) [[environmental sciences]]; among others.http://alice.euroinvestor.fr/news/story.aspx?id=10649149{{cite web|url=http://www.desu.edu/phd-program-optics |title=PhD Program in Optics |publisher=Desu.edu |accessdate=2011-09-19}} Major grants are awarded through the [[United States Department of Defense|U.S. Department of Defense]], [[National Institutes of Health]], [[National Science Foundation]], [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] and other granting agencies.{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/office-associate-provost-research|title=Office of the Associate Provost for Research|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}} ===Rankings=== DSU is placed among Tier 2 Regional Universities (North) in ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'''s annual "Best Colleges".{{cite web |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/delaware-state-university-130934/overall-rankings|title=Delaware State University - Rankings|work=U.S. News & World Report|year=2011}} The College of Business at DSU is one of the nation's most outstanding business schools, according to [[the Princeton Review]]. The Princeton Review and [[Random House]] have selected the college for their 2009 edition book to be recognized as one of "The 269 Best Business Schools" in the U.S. offering quality [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] programs. It was also listed in "The Best 301 Business Schools"-2010, "The Best 300 Business Schools"-2011 and "The Best 294 Business Schools"-2012 editions.{{cite web |url=http://www.princetonreview.com/PRAIRIESTATECOLLEGE.aspx|title=Delaware State University College of Business - Rankings and Lists|publisher=The Princeton Review and Random House|year=2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/princeton-review-names-dsu-college-business-among-top-business-schools|title=Princeton Review Names College of Business Among Top Business Schools|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2011}} ===Global connections=== The university has over thirty formal international partnerships with institutions in countries including [[China]], [[Cuba]], [[Egypt]], [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], [[Korea]], [[Mexico]], [[Nigeria]], [[Poland]] and the [[United Kingdom|UK]] which facilitate research and conference collaborations as well as student exchanges.{{cite web |url=http://www.desu.edu/faculty-research-abroad|title=Faculty Research Abroad|publisher=Delaware State University|year=2009}} ==Student activities== === Athletics === The university fields teams, who are known as the [[Hornet]]s, in: {{multicol|65%}} *[[baseball]] *[[basketball]] (men's and women's) *[[bowling]] *[[college football|football]] *[[Association football|soccer]] {{col-break}} *[[softball]] *[[track and field]] *[[tennis]] *[[volleyball]] {{col-end}} The [[College athletics|athletic]] programs participate in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]'s (NCAA)'s [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] (I-AA for football). The Hornets compete in the [[Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference]] as full members since the conference was founded in 1970. The university's Department of Intramural Sports provides a wide variety of quality recreational programs for students, faculty and staff. ====Football==== {{see also|Delaware State Hornets football}} The football team won the 2007 MEAC football championship with a win over [[Norfolk State University]] with a score of 28 to 21 in overtime giving them an automatic bid into the [[2007 NCAA Division I FCS football season#Postseason|NCAA Division I FCS (Football Championship Subdivision) playoffs]]. During that tournament the Hornets lost to the University of Delaware with a score of 44-7 in the first round, the first-ever meeting between the two schools. DSU and UD now compete for the First State Cup as part of the [[Route 1 Rivalry]] games during the regular season. The Hornets also lost the games played in 2009 and 2011. ====Basketball==== The university has both men's and women's basketball teams. Its men's basketball team won the 2005 MEAC championship and earned a berth in the 2005 NCAA tournament. Playing as a sixteen-seed, the Hornets lost 57-46 in the opening round to one-seed [[Duke University]].{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=254000032|title=Coach K Ties Smith for Most NCAA Tourney Wins|accessdate=2008-11-30}} The Hornets also have made back to back [[National Invitation Tournament]] appearances in 2006 and 2007. The women's basketball team won the 2006 MEAC championship and earned a berth in the 2006 NCAA tournament. Playing as a fifteen-seed, the Lady Hornets kept the game close down by only three until nine minutes remained in the game, but lost 62-47 in the opening round to two-seed [[Vanderbilt University]].{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores107/107077/NCAAW763069.htm|title=USA Today Woman's Basketball|accessdate=2008-11-30 | date=2006-04-18}} ==Notable alumni== {{AlumniStart}} {{Alum|name=[[Reggie Barnes]]|year=1988|nota=[[Canadian Football League]] [[running back]], various teams, 1990-1996}} {{Alum|name=[[Clyde Bishop]]|nota=[[United States Ambassador to the Marshall Islands|U.S. Ambassador to the Marshall Islands]], since 2006}} {{Alum|name=[[Clifford Brown]]|nota|nota=[[trumpet]] [[virtuoso]], [[composer]], an influential and highly rated American jazz musician}} {{Alum|name=[[George F. Budd]]|nota=president, [[St. Cloud State University]], 1952-1965; president, Kansas State College of Pittsburg (since 1977, [[Pittsburg State University]]), 1965-1977|ref}} {{Alum|name=Ralph Wesley|year=2003|nota=Public Address Announcer for the Washington Wizards{{cite web|url=http://www.hbcudigest.com/2010/09/delaware-state-alum-ralph-wesley-named-washington-wizards-pa-announcer/|title=Delaware State Alum Ralph Wesley Named Washington Wizardsâ P.A. Announcer }}}} {{Alum|name=[[Emanual Davis]]|year=1991|nota=Former NBA player for the Atlanta Hawks, and Seattle Supersonics}} {{Alum|name=[[Wayne Gilchrest]]|year=1973|nota=[[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for [[Maryland's 1st congressional district]], 1990â2009}} {{Alum|name=[[Jamaal Jackson]]|year=2003|nota=[[National Football League]] [[offensive lineman]], [[Philadelphia Eagles]], since 2004}} {{Alum|name=[[Maxine R. Lewis]]|year=1973|nota= [[publicist]], [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[television network]]}} {{Alum|name=[[Quincy A. Lucas]]|year=2004|nota= [[advocate]] against [[domestic violence]]; speaker, [[2008 Democratic National Convention]]}} {{Alum|name=[[Marlene Saunders]]|year=1967|nota=2008 [[Delaware]] [[social worker]] of the year; also [[professor]], [[scholar]] and [[historian]]|ref}} {{Alum|name=[[Harley F. Taylor]]|year=1929|nota=housing developer and creator of oldest African-American housing development in [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]], [[Delaware]]}} {{Alum|name=[[John Taylor (football player)|John Taylor]]|year=1986|nota=[[National Football League]] [[wide receiver]], [[San Francisco 49ers]], 1987â1995}} {{Alum|name=[[Bonsu Thompson]]|nota=[[Editor-In-Chief]], ''[[The Source (magazine)|The Source]]'' magazine}} {{Alum|name=[[Walter Tullis]]|nota=[[National Football League]] [[wide receiver]], [[Green Bay Packers]]}} {{Alum|name=[[David G. Turner]]|year=1986|nota=executive, [[Bank of America]], recognized by ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine in 2002 as one of the "50 most powerful black executives in America"}} {{Alum|name=[[Robert London II]]|year=1998|nota=[[National Football League]] [[sports agent]]}} {{Alum|name=[[Darnerien McCants]]|year=2001|nota=[[National Football League]] [[wide receiver]], Currently a free agent}} {{Alum|name=[[Shaheer McBride]]|year=2008|nota=[[National Football League]] [[wide receiver]], Currently a free agent, plays for [[United Football League (2009â)|UFL's]] [[Hartford Colonials]]}} {{end}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Additional references== *{{cite web|year=2005|url=http://www.desu.edu/dsu/history.php|title=Delaware State University Accreditation (History)|publisher=Delaware State University|accessdate=2006-05-22 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060206105710/http://www.desu.edu/dsu/history.php |archivedate = February 6, 2006}}
